author: GRACE CHEN
title: Down-and-out veteran singer agrees to seek help

organizations.name: volunteers unite and teddy mobile clinic

text:
by grace chen Ben as he was during his heyday in the late 1980s 
ANY plans of a comeback by Ben Nathan will have to wait until he has fully recovered, said Yayasan Artis 1Malaysia (YA1M) president Datuk Irwan Shah Abdullah, better known as DJ Dave. 
Dave, who was by Ben’s side when he was escorted to Hospital Kuala Lumpur by the police and four social welfare officers, said Ben had agreed to cooperate after assurances that he would not be jailed. 
“At first, he told me to leave as he kept insisting there was nothing wrong with him. 
“He kept saying he had to go to Jakarta for a recording and that he had found a sponsor from Penang,” said Dave. 
Ben as he was during his heyday in the late 1980s. 
Commenting on media reports surrounding the former 80s singer, Dave said this was not his first encounter with Ben. 
Six months ago, Dave spotted Ben on the street on two different occasions. 
“The first time was near the Muzium Negara MRT Station. 
“The second was near Sri Kota in Brickfields. 
“Both times I asked him to come with me so I could buy him food and new clothes. 
“But he kept saying he was okay. 
“He insisted he had to go for a meeting and asked me for my business card so he could contact me later,” said Dave, who reconnected with Ben after a photo of the dishevelled singer went viral. 
The YA1M president said he was informed by hospital authorities that Ben would be kept under observation for a week. 
Dave (right) says he had run into Ben (left) twice in the last six months but Ben was unwilling then to seek help. 
With regard to the charity concert to raise funds for Ben, Dave said a meeting has been scheduled for next Tuesday with Tan Sri Syed Mohd Yusof Syed Nasir of Jojo Events. 
However, there were no concrete plans for the fundraising concert yet. 
Volunteers Unite and Teddy Mobile Clinic co-founder Alfred Samuel Mariyaras, who has worked with street people for the last four years, said from his experience it would not be easy to deal with Ben. 
“People who have just come off the streets into a home or institution may not like the sudden curtailing of their personal freedom. 
“There is a high probability that he may run off again,” he said. 
Mariyaras suggested that to keep him off the streets, Ben should be in a place surrounded by loved ones who can constantly assure him that he is needed and appreciated.
